overview.summary: COMP 321 provides a foundational understanding of computer systems from a programmer's perspective, covering assembly language, memory management, and system-level programming.  It builds upon prior programming knowledge to provide a deeper understanding of how software interacts with hardware.
learningObjectives: Understand the fundamentals of assembly language programming
Explain the concepts of the memory hierarchy and caching
Implement system-level programs using C or a similar language
Understand process management and inter-process communication
Apply knowledge of computer architecture to improve program performance

recommendedPreparation: Familiarity with data structures and algorithms

professors.teachingStyle: A mix of lectures, coding demonstrations, and problem-solving sessions.  Emphasis on hands-on learning.
professors.availability: Office hours are typically held twice a week, with additional availability by appointment.

statistics.enrollmentTrend: Stable.  Consistent demand for this core computer science course.

careerProspects.salaryImpact: Strong foundation for higher-paying roles in software engineering and related fields.

recommendations.timeManagement: Allocate sufficient time each week for lectures, labs, assignments, and studying.
resources: Online resources on assembly language and system programming

uniqueAspects: Focus on practical applications of computer systems concepts
Strong emphasis on debugging and low-level programming
commonMistakes: Underestimating the difficulty of assembly language
Insufficient attention to details in code
successFactors: Active participation in class and labs
